results.notes:
Leccinum holopus (Rostk.) Watling, Boletaceae, Agaricales. (Local name: Подберёзовик светлый или Подберёзовик болотный)
Cap: 6-15cm convex up to broadly convex; surface is smooth with thin skin; brownish-white or light brown. Odour is fragrant. Flesh is white and the older the softer.
Tubes: attached, colour from white up to light brown, sometimes pinkish-white; old tubes imbibe water as a sponge.
Stalk: 6-16cm long with tiny projections as dark dots, colour white up to dull brownish-white or light brown; 1.5-3cm thick, enlarged down; old one is fibrous and stiff; sometimes has bluish colouring at the base (when old).
Habitat: single or small group near birches mainly in wet places of pine-tree forest.
Edibility: good (several methods of cooking).
June – September.

results.notes:
TZ #107
Collection date: April 5, 2016
Collector: Johannes (Johann) Harnisch.
Location: Mafinga Iringa Tanzania,
Near 6000 feet elevation,
GPS – UTM
36M 730,260.2e
9068627.7n
Amanita muscaria group, collected under 3 needle pine.
Solitary or in groups,
Medium to large Amanita with orange red pileus,
One specimen described here
Total height 160mm
Pileus: width 110mm, margin grooved, surface smooth, moist, universal veil washed off pileus surface. Margin turned upward (concave), surface orange with yellow undertones. Flesh soft, max 11mm deep.
Lamellae: nearly close, margin minutely jagged, distantly free (10mm), not all lamellae extend entire distance from (beginning at) pileus margin to stipe apex. Dull white, 11mm deep.

Odor: faint
Stipe: length 10m (measured from apex to top of bulb base). Slightly stuffed with white cotton like material. 25mm wide at base (right above bulb), 11mm wide at apex, tapering upward. Dull white, exterior covered with fine cotton like material. patches of universal veil remaining near base.
Veil: on stipe in upper quarter, membrane and cotton like. White.
Bulb base: globular, covered with angular cotton like patches of universal veil, white, solid, 35mm long, 40mm wide.

results.notes: Within a triangle formed by 3 Doug Fir near a trash pile of construction wood, OSB. Discriminated from C. rachodes by single ring edge, abruptly bulbous base; C. olivieri by stem to cap diameter ratio. C. olivieri 1.5; this mushroom less than 1.2: 16:14 cm (fully opened), 13:11 cm (nearly fully opened). – two specimens. Other features – “shaggy” cap, reddening stem when buised on the outside or cut. White spore print, white gills, free gills. Inconsistency, I cannot identify a ridge at the top of the bulbous base. Five of these, roughly equal in size, were growing as a cluster within a two foot circle.

results.notes:
On weathered sandstone bedrock outcropping in a semi-arid grassland setting.

This is the first time I’ve come across this taxon in my many forays in this area. It more resembles Acarospora thamnina in overall appearance, and may be this species. But the negative C reaction on the thallus cortex and medulla steers it clear of this ID and puts it at Acarospora obnubila. However, I have struggled with C tests on Acarospora and don’t consider the negative result to be bullet proof. I did do the spot test under dissection scope at 20x and under compound scope at 100×. Anyway, here’s the description notes:

Thallus squamulose, light brown above with black underside (A. obnubila is white, A. thamnina is black) and a long narrow black stipe (both species have a stipe), cortex C-, KC? kind of barely reddish, but a note in Nash Sonoran Flora for A. obnubila says “apparently cortical pigment diffuses in K looking yellowish or reddish brown”. I got definitely K-, but adding C seemed to give a slight reddish tint. Medulla white, C- to maybe every so slightly pinkish. Algal layer beneath thallus cortex is interrupted with hyphal bundles (more consistent with A. obnubila). Apothecia lecanorine, rather uncommon, irregularly shaped, immersed, roughened, reddish brown. Algal layer thin but continuous across base into margin. Pycnidia abundant (not seen in Sonoran material of A. thamnina, but common for A. obnubila), laminal, often with cracks on thallus connecting them.

Spores greater than 50/ascus, simple, hyaline, small. 5.6×2.4, 4.8×2.1, 4.3×2.2, 4.8×1.9

This specimen doesn’t look like any of my other collections of so called
Lecidea atrobrunnea group or Lecidea fuscoatra, but for some reason I expected it belongs somewhere in there. The ID of Lecidea mannii is consistent in spore size, chemistry and looks just like other photos online.

Thallus composed of light brown, shiny, convex areoles with black, plane, dull, apothecia on margins. Most areoles K-, but I did get a couple spots with K+R in small localized areas. Cortex C-. Medulla C+R in localized areas, fading quickly. Apothecia often squished up against another, disk rough, epruinose, 1-3 per areole. Apothecia are thin vertically, often taking the shape of the areole they are on, causing them to vary from concave to convex, but typically plane. Thalline margin absent. Exciple C- at 400×. Epihymenium black. Hymenium hyaline, hypothecium dingy brown.

Spores small, simple to maybe 1-septate, hyaline. Measurements: 12.2×6.2, 13.3×5.7, 12.5×5.6, 14.4×5.7, 13.4×6.1

results.notes:
Description

Pileus: 41-61 × 9-16 mm; flattened globose to pulvinate when young, then convex, eventually with depressed centre and somewhat opened up; margin sulcate-pectinate; smooth at first with somewhat velutinouse shine, velum breaking up radially into irregular, often areolate, appressed patches starting halfway towards the margin when expanding, then the grooved margin becomes more evident, velum stays intact in the centre, surface tad whitish with some of the specimens and rough, especially towards the margin; surface somewhat viscid-greasy to the touch, later faintly greasy to dry; at first uniform black-brown to dark brown, soon with lighter areas, eventually entirely slightly paler, sepia to (dark) grey-brown with some ochraceous tinges in the centre of some specimens, surface underneath the velum is paler sepia- to greyish-brown; often with rusty stains; margin eventually split; pileipellis peels to ½ of the pileus.

Lamellae: Fairly crowded, emarginate to slightly running down apex, often furcate with some specimens, narrow and low intervenose; margin even; cream coloured with slight brownish-yellow tinge and greyish shade, later with rusty stains and slightly brunnescent margin.

Stipe: 25-54 × 12-20 mm; central to slightly eccentric; irregularly cylindrical, clavate to squat and tapering towards the base, often bent; surface dry, irregular, finely rugulose, apex finely appressed floccose; with rusty stains, especially on the base; greyish-white with sometimes somewhat rusty shade.

Context: Firm at first, later brittle; slightly darker in cortex when fresh (directly after cross-section); stipe soon cavernous; spongy-looking in the core of the stipe; whitish with later rusty stains, especially in the base, brownish directly beneath pileipellis when fresh.

Smell/Taste: Not very strongly scented at first, but after picking and contained for a while and cross-section, then rancid, faint spermatic; taste: pileipellis: mild; pileal context: mild, then faintly acrid; lamellae: acrid with “soapy”/sourish component; stipital context: mild, then faintly acrid.
 
Microscopy:

- Spores: Subglobose to broadly ellipsoid, obvious apiculus with small dimple above; mainly loose, sometimes tad thicker warts (< 1 µm), some spores with ridges and some spores with some connectivity between the warts.
- Measurements: (1000x, oil-immersion, Melzers + H2O, 1 sd=1,02 µm)

Length Width Q-ratio

Spore 1 8,16 5,1 1,6
Spore 2 8,16 5,1 1,6
Spore 3 8,16 6,12 1,333333333
Spore 4 8,16 5,1 1,6
Spore 5 7,14 6,12 1,166666667
Spore 6 8,16 5,1 1,6
Spore 7 7,14 6,12 1,166666667
Spore 8 7,14 6,12 1,166666667
Spore 9 7,14 5,1 1,4
Spore 10 8,16 5,1 1,6

Minimum 7,1 5,1
Maximum 8,2 6,1
Average 7,8 5,5 1,423333333

- Basidia: 4-sterigmate
- Cheilocystidia: Numerous, fusiform, not measured
- Velum: Heavily branched, very irregular and tortuous, with many vacuoles

Chemical analysis: Orangy pink reaction to FeSO4 on in- and exterior stipe and pileal context, fades to soft pink; very faint reaction to KOH 3% on in- and exterior stipe and pileal context, bloodred on the exterior base of the stipe.

Ecology: Terrestrial, on an old, relatively oligotrophic “roadside” on sandy soils, associated with Quercus robur and an adjoining hedge of Fagus sylvatica. Accompanied by Hebeloma sp., Mycena galopus var. galopus, Russula graveolens and Xerocomus sp.

Discussion:

Three photographs of this collection showed up on my facebookfeed, as it was posted in my Belgian/Dutch mushroom identification group “Paddenstoelen”. Looking at the remarkably areolate pileus, it occured to me that it might be a very interesting species of Russula, since we have very few species with such a pileal texture in the Netherlands. While I gazed in awe at the photos a for a while, I found the pileal margin was sulcate and that, in combination with the dull colours and stout stature, these mushrooms might be a species from the R. amoenolens group, like R. sororia.

So I took a look in Kibby’s Russula monograph for the British Isles, only to find R. sororia does not have a cracked cap, but the closely related rarity called R. pseudoaffinis does! And after checking some collections online, I was stunned by the striking similarities. Now I know most Russula are near to impossible to identify from photographic material, even from high quality shots, without any info on macro- and microcharacteristics, macro- and microchemical analysis and ecological circumstances, but this was a match (so I felt). And if it happened to be R. pseudoaffinis, then it would mean we have a new and wonderful species of Russula to add to the Dutch checklist!

I shared my thoughts with the person who posted the collection and also asked if I could come over to take a look and some samples for further investigation. And so it happened! The day after I went to see two members of the local mushroom group who found the specimens the day before. With all the excitement I gained new friends who share my love for Fungi. It is great how likeminded people can connect via social media!

Back to the mushroom. Meanwhile I was asking around for keys and descriptions for Russula subgenus Ingratula, Russula pseudoaffinis and Russula sororia f. pseudoaffinis, since I only have Kibby’s work to compare this particular and likely rare species with. Luckily friends from Cyprus, Belgium, India and the Netherlands came to the rescue and sent me the information I required to solve this mystery. Chiel Noordeloos also recommended to contact Jaap Wisman, one of our Dutch Russula specialists, who apparently has all the latest and most important Russula literature.

After photographing and describing the whole collection, I received an email back from Jaap, in which he states that I should also look into R. insignis and R. praetervisa. The first was easily recognized by the bloodred reaction to KOH on the exterior of the base of the stipe, the latter was found once last year in a molecular study after being mislabeled as R. insignis. After reading his advise, I remember I hadn’t done the KOH on stipe base test and my collection was already dried… Ah well, let’s try anyway. And yes, it did turn red… But after reading up on both suggested species in various sources, I was stumped. Because the reaction on the stipes base was there, but literature states both R. insignis and R. praetervisa should taste mild, where my collection was acrid, especially and quite strongly in the lamellae.

Mailed back to Jaap with the description, photos, source list and lots of questions and still awaiting answer… I’ll update when I have more information!

If anyone has an idea, please do share your thoughts! I’m very eager to find out what this beauty is called and whether I can tell my friends they have the honour of finding a new species of Russula for the Netherlands.

results.notes:
Bot_1024/2016_DSC6239

Habitat: Mixed forest, Fagus sylvatica and Picea abies dominant trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; relatively warm and dry place; colluvial, calcareous, skeletal ground; in shade; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 600 m (2.000 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: completely rotten stump of Picea abies.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, near the trail from Trenta 2b cottage to abandoned farm house Strgulc, Soča 47, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Pluteus pouzarianus belongs to Pluteus cervinus agg. Variability of size, color, etc. of members of this group is so big that several authors claim they can hardly be determined in the field. Microscopy is needed. Pluteus pouzarianus is distinguished from other options, particularly from common Pluteus cervinus s.s., by: about 40% of hypha in pileipellis having clamps and it grows exclusively on conifer wood. Usually it has (in average) grayer cap and it is of somewhat smaller size. It seems, traits of the find fit well to literature.

There were two pilei present in this find. Pilei diameter 4 and 4.5 cm, surface velvety-waxy for palpation, cuticle peels off easily; stipe 4.5 and 5 cm tall, diameter in the middle 6 and 6.5 mm, ‘bulbous’; SP abundant, pinkish-ocher, oac651.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes: In the white conical stage of growth pileus was pure white with patches exterior of pileus. When mushroom matured out of the white conical stage the pileus widened out to convex form and was gray with small white patches. At this stage pileus was smooth, shiny and moist to touch. At this stage gills were mostly black with small area of white at top of gills near underside of pileus. Gills were unattached. Stipe remained white through all stages of maturity. Deterioration of pileus was signaled by the “upturning of pileus” as if to fold gills over top of pileus. As deterioration progressed pileus completely deteriorated leaving blackish spot on top of stipe. I was fortunate to find this growth with examples of all stages of maturity .

results.notes:
Two observations:
Dat.: June 7. 2013, Code: Bot_721/2013_DSC6505+IMG3521
Picture file names: from Tubulifera-arachnoidea_raw_1 to Tubulifera-arachnoidea_raw_11
and
Dat.: June 9. 2013, Code: Bot_723/2013_DSC6562
Picture file names: Tubulifera-arachnoidea_raw_20.

Habitat: Mountain pasture, slightly inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; skeletal, colluvial, calcareous ground; full sun; dry and relatively warm place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitation ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 610 m (2.000 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: a piece of partly rotten trunk of Picea abies lying on ground.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, Na Melu place near the cottage Trenta 2b, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comment: Tubulifera arachnoidea, former Tubifera ferruginosa is a complex of several taxa. Several taxa on var. and subsp. level have been described; however Index Fungorum (still?) considers all of them as synonyms. The last revision of this complex (to my knowledge) from 2015 (Ref.1) has defined Tubifera ferruginosa (Batsch) Gmel. subsp. ferruginosa Leontyev, Schnittler & S.L. Stephenson, subsp. nov. also on DNA level. Its description fits well to the observed traits of this find. MycoBank keeps Tubulifera arachnoidea as the current name, while Index Fungorum keeps both names Tubulifera arachnoidea and Tubulifera ferruginosa as current (?). I keep with Ref.4 naming.

Ref.:
(1) D.V. Leontyev, M. Schnittler, S.L. Stephenson, A critical revision of the Tubifera ferruginosa complex, Mycologia, 107(5) (2015), pp. 959–985.
(2) B. Ing, The Myxomycetes of Britain and Ireland, The Richmond Publ. Co.Ltd, (1999), p 95
(3) S.L.Stephenson and H.Stempen, Myxomycetes, Timber Press Inc.(2000), p 159
(4) M. Poulain, M. Meyer, J. Borronet, Les Myxomycetes, FMBDS (2011), Vol.1., p 316; Vol.2. p 47.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes:
On intruded siliceous rock in a dry wash along Bitterwater Road in eastern San Luis Obispo County.

Thallus brown, areolate to subsquamulose, mostly flat to slightly convex. Cortex 10-15µm thick, yellowish to reddish brown in section. Medulla white, about 15µm thick. Individual areoles with 1-3 apothecia per areole. Apothecia immersed, flush with thallus, encompassing the width of the areole in age. Disks dark reddish, rough, without pruina, dark thin parathecial crown present but disk not elevated by crown. Hymenium hyaline, hypothecium dingy, epihymenium yellowish to reddish brown, algal layer thick and continuous below, paraphyses less than 2µm wide at base. Cortex and medulla C-, checked at 400×.

Spores probably >100 per ascus, small, hyaline, ellipsoid.
Average size 5.3 × 2.4µm (n=9)

results.notes:
Found by Joe Cohen. Growing in mixed conifer forest, on a mound covered with a thin layer of duff, an area about 1 m^2. It was raining and we didn’t get any in situ photos. (And then the only one I took when we got home is out of focus!) Gill in at least some of the mushrooms were definitely reddish (pinkish-red?) marginate. Sadly, I didn’t note the odor.

Basidia 4-spored ~22+4 x 8. Spores 6-7 × 3.5-4. Cheilocystidia not forming a band, 45-68 × 11-15. No pleurocystidia. Hyphae of the pileipellis covered densely with long (up to 50 microns) excrescences, 1-2 microns wide. Hyphae of the cortical layer of the stipe diverticulate, with terminal cells (see photo), but also with wildly branching excrescences (near stipe apex) 1.5-2.5 microns wide.

The spores are unusually small for the section Rubromarginatae. No name I can find in the literature seems to deserve even a “could be” match.

[7 Nov 2016] Brian Perry suggests this is M. rosella. And indeed, what I saw as cheilocystidia were the abundant pleurocystidia. Only now I’m seeing the real cheilocystidia; they are smaller and there is less of them visible, even though they do make a contiguous band on the gill edge.

results.notes:
[Pacific Nortwest Key Council foray; thanks to Fred Rhoades for the company and for finding a spectacular room-sized spot where this and many other mushrooms were growing.]

A single specimen, growing from a crack in a burned and rotten conifer log.

M. fuliginella is unusual: (1) amyloid spores combined with non-dextrinoid trama, (2) absence of an honest pileipellis and pigmented cells there instead. These characters make it a unique Mycena, and we have them in this observation. Everything else from Smith’s description seems to be a good match too, except for a slight difference in spore size (but not shape) and the missing “low broad umbo”.

Smith didn’t look at caulocystidia. Maas Geesteranus found them “mostly geniculate and curved outward”. I made a few attempts to demostrate ‘geniculate’, but didn’t get to see entire caulocystidia clearly.

It is perhaps interesting that one of Smith’s collections was found “on charred conifer stump” (http://storage.idigbio.org/...).

Ceska’s Observation 86437 and Observation 168340 seem to be the only recent reports on this species. The photo in Observation 86437 looks quite different from ours. The colors of the cap (for which Smith uses terms ‘fuscous’, ‘Saccardo umber’, ‘fuliginous’, etc.) and gills (‘whitish’, ‘grayish’) seem to be more closely matched in our observation. And the stype: ‘hyaline white’.

results.notes: This was found on a lot where a home was torn down several years ago-New Paris, Ohio. There were at least 3 clusters of varying growth present but rather scattered. There are 2 old stumps present-one was maple. There is a row of old conifer trees several feet away. There were at least 4 species of mushrooms present on this lot-most likely from buried tree roots. These were soft, velvety, with very fine residue on the surface. They have very small pores that seem to run down the stipe. They were in clusters but having single stipes. The surface does peel easily. Spore print was either non existent or very fine white. The edges of this mushroom did give a brown liquid during the spore printing. The largest one was at least 10 inches in width-pileus and at least 8 inches in height. The stipe on the sample I took was about 2 inches in width. I did not measure or disturb the largest one. The smell was very pleasant almost sweet-reminded me of older bananas.

Called “var. subvellereus” in Milk Mushrooms of NA.

Gills on this specimen repeatedly forked.

results.notes:
These were growing on the ground(humus?) in mixed woods @ ~ 3700 ft.
Caps up to 4.1 cm and somewhat viscid.
Spore print brown and spores rather pale in 1% KOH under microscope.
Spores ~ 8.1-9.9 X 5.1-6.1 microns, ellipsoid to elongate(Q avg = 1.60)
My ID proposal is based mostly on my MO#122531….looks and spores are similar.
